[[File:cerne-abbas-giant-2001-cropped.jpg|thumb|The [[Cerne Abbas Giant]] chalk figure, near the village of [[Cerne Abbas]] in [[Dorset]], England, is made by a turf-cut.]] [[File:Uffington-White-Horse-sat.jpg|thumb|alt=A stylised figure of a white horse cut into the hillside.|The [[Uffington White Horse]] at [[Uffington, Oxfordshire]]]] [[File:Paragliding above Westbury White Horse - geograph.org.uk - 539764.jpg|thumb|alt=Figure of a white horse cut into the hillside.|The 18th-century [[Westbury White Horse]] near [[Westbury, Wiltshire]]]]
A '''hill figure''' is a large visual representation created by cutting into a steep hillside and revealing the underlying geology. It is a type of [[geoglyph]] usually designed to be seen from afar rather than above. In some cases trenches are dug and rubble made from material brighter than the natural [[bedrock]] is placed into them. The new material is often [[chalk]], a soft and white form of [[limestone]], leading to the alternative name of '''chalk figure''' for this form of art.
Hill figures cut in grass are a phenomenon especially seen in [[England]], where examples include the [[Cerne Abbas Giant]], the [[Uffington White Horse]], the [[Long Man of Wilmington]], as well as the "lost" carvings at [[Cambridge]], [[Oxford]] and [[Plymouth Hoe]]. From the 18th century onwards, many further ones were added. Many figures long thought to be ancient have been found to be relatively recent when subjected to modern archaeological scrutiny, at least in their current form. Only the Uffington White Horse appears to retain a prehistoric shape, while the Cerne Abbas Giant may be prehistoric, Romano-British, or Early Modern. Nevertheless, these figures, and their possible lost companions, have been iconic in the English people's conception of their past.
==History== The creation of hill figures has been practised since [[prehistory]] and can include human and animal forms. Cutting of horses is common, as well as more abstract symbols and, in the modern era, advertising brands.
The reasons for the creation for the figures are varied and obscure. The Uffington Horse probably held political significance, since the figure dominates the valley below. It probably dates to the [[British Iron Age]] since coins have been found exhibiting the symbol. The Cerne Abbas Giant might have been a work of [[political satire]].<ref name="sd">{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-destinations.com/england/cerne-abbas-giant.htm|title=Cerne Abbas Giant|author=|date=|work=sacred-destinations.com}}</ref> [[Wiltshire]] is a [[Ceremonial counties of England|county]] with a large number of White Horses; 14 have been recorded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiltshirewhitehorses.org.uk/index.html|title=Wiltshire White Horses|author=|date=|work=wiltshirewhitehorses.org.uk}}</ref> The figures are usually created by the cutting away of the top layer of relatively poor soil on suitable hillsides. This exposes the white chalk beneath, which contrasts well with the short green hill grass, and the image is clearly visible for a considerable distance. Despite most of the figures being of great age, many are relatively new. [[Devizes]] in Wiltshire created a large white horse for the 2000 Millennium celebrations and in October 2009 celebrated this with an aerial photo of volunteers making the figure 10 for an aerial photo.<ref>{{cite web|title=Roundway Hill and covert, Oliver's castle and Millennium White Horse|url=http://www.devizesheritage.org.uk/olivers_castle_and_roundway_hill.html|website=devizeheritage.org.uk|accessdate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304180203/http://www.devizesheritage.org.uk/olivers_castle_and_roundway_hill.html|archivedate=4 March 2015|df=}}</ref>
Figures must be maintained to remain visible, and local people often work regularly to restore or maintain a local landmark, though two cuttings of military badges at [[Sutton Mandeville]], Wiltshire, are becoming lost. A map of [[Australia]] at [[Compton Chamberlayne]], Wiltshire, was lost in 2005.
Similar pictures exist elsewhere in the world, notably the far larger [[Nazca Lines]] in [[Peru]], which are on flat land but visible from hills in the area. However these were made in desert terrain rather than on grassy hillsides, so have not become overgrown and thus have survived much longer without maintenance. The Nazca Lines were formed by removing loose stones from the lines to expose the whiteish underlying soil, which is not itself dug.
===Terminology===
[[Geoglyph]] is the usual term for structures carved into or otherwise made from rock formations.
In 1949, Morris Marples "half-humorously" coined the words "leucippotomy for the cutting of white horses and gigantotomy for the cutting of giants on rare occasions".<ref>Morris Marples, "White horses and other hill figures", Publisher: A. Sutton, 1949 (reprint), {{ISBN|0904387593}}, 9780904387599, 223 pages, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=t1B3UOLHFcWr0QWd3YGQAw&id=5Q4aAAAAYAAJ&dq=Gigantotomy+morris&q=Gigantotomy+Leucippotomy#search_anchor page 16]</ref><ref>John Timpson, "Timpson's Other England: A Look at the Unusual and the Definitely Odd", Publisher: Jarrold, 1994, {{ISBN|071170645X}}, 9780711706453, 224 pages, [https://books.google.com/books?id=v3KCYyLL8bEC&q=Gigantotomy+Leucippotomy.&dq=Gigantotomy+Leucippotomy.&source=bl&ots=OtUHgPVsF9&sig=usNFWidsu94Pd2LfevxpNffiVI8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CFyFUM22LIb80QXPyoDIBA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAg page 68] </ref><ref>Harold William Timperley, "The Vale of Pewsey", Publisher Hale, 1954, 230 pages, [https://books.google.com/books?id=bgJIAAAAMAAJ&q=Gigantotomy+Leucippotomy.&dq=Gigantotomy+Leucippotomy.&source=bl&ots=6qXUCMKUc5&sig=6o0gOf9i7SfgUHJwjEiZIlSu2tU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CFyFUM22LIb80QXPyoDIBA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAw page 181]</ref> Though neither word appears in the [[Oxford English Dictionary]], the terms occasionally appear in print.<ref>"Top 10: Britain's largest hill figures", The Telegraph, undated, attributed to ''Top 10 of Britain: 250 Quintessentially British Lists'' by Russell Ash, published by Hamlyn</ref>
==Construction== Until recently, three methods were used to construct white hill figures.
*The stripping method: where the soil is thin, the turf or soil is stripped away to expose the chalk underneath. This produces quick results but the figure needs regular maintenance, as it would soon become overgrown. This was a practice for hill figures but not as much for horses. The Laverstock Panda at [[Laverstock]] near Salisbury, Wiltshire was constructed this way in 1968 and is now lost. Traces of figures of this type are not usually found after the figure is overgrown. *The covering method: rocks are placed on top of the turf. This method is normally used when there is no underlying chalk, the chalk is deep or tools are not available. The maintenance for these figures is very high. There are several examples, such as the [[Woolbury White Horse]] in Hampshire. This method leaves no trace of the figure's existence when overgrown, as is the case of the lost [[Fovant Badges]] in Wiltshire. *The trenching method, which is by far the most common method of hill figure construction. The underlying chalk where some white horses are constructed is not near the surface, so a trench is dug and chalk from another site is used to fill it. The [[Uffington White Horse]] in Oxfordshire is the prime example of this method. This method is invasive in the hillside and allows traces of the figure to be seen even when the figure has been overgrown for many years, an example being the original [[Devizes White Horse]], cut in 1845 and lost sometime in the mid 20th century, but rediscovered when traces reappeared.
The biggest threat to white horses and other hill figures is natural vegetation covering the figures. In the case of chalk figures, natural vegetation encroaches from the edges and can grow on soil washed onto the figure by rain. Water erosion can also be a problem on steep or gentle slopes, because rain can wash the chalk off the horse, or soil onto the horse. Larger horses are more susceptible to this. If chalk is washed off the horse, the horse gradually creeps down the slope; or if soil is washed onto the horse, it collects onto the lower edges and the horse gradually climbs up the slope. A solution is to provide drainage, either using run-off drains, as at Uffington White Horse, or a [[french ditch]].
==Human figures== While presumed to be of [[Prehistory|prehistoric]] origin, surviving examples may have been created only within the last four hundred years.<ref Name="Bergamar">Bergamar, Kate (1997). Discovering Hill Figures. Pub. Shire. {{ISBN|0-7478-0345-5}}.</ref> Of these giants only two survive: one near the village of [[Cerne Abbas]], to the north of [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]], in [[Dorset]] and one at Wilmington, [[Long Man]] [[civil parish]] in the [[Wealden District|Wealden]] District of [[East Sussex]]. Examples located at [[Oxford]], [[Cambridge]], and on [[Plymouth Hoe]] can no longer be seen with the naked eye.<ref Name="Bergamar"/><ref name=wilt>{{cite web|title=Prehistorical Wiltshire|url=http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/statue/1287/English/Salisbur/stoneh1.htm|website=fortunecity.com|accessdate=5 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040315152542/http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/statue/1287/English/Salisbur/stoneh1.htm|archivedate=15 March 2004|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="giants">{{cite web|url=http://www.waysideofwiltshire.co.uk/holiday-accommodation-chippenham.html|title=Wayside of Wiltshire|author=|date=|work=Bed & Breakfast and Self Catering Holiday Accommodation in beautiful Wiltshire|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410044604/http://www.waysideofwiltshire.co.uk/holiday-accommodation-chippenham.html|archivedate=2013-04-10|df=}}</ref>
The [[Osmington White Horse]] carries a rider ([[King George III]]) but is not considered an example of gigantotomy due to the name of the figure referring to the horse.
===Cerne Abbas Giant=== {{main|Cerne Abbas Giant}} The [[Cerne Abbas Giant]], also referred to as the "Rude Man" or the "Rude Giant", is a hill figure of a giant naked man {{convert|180|ft|abbr=on}} high, {{convert|167|ft|abbr=on}} wide<ref name="sd"/> figure is carved into the side of a steep hill, and is best viewed from the opposite side of the valley or from the air. The carving is formed by a [[trench]] {{convert|12|in|cm|abbr=on}} wide,<ref name="sd" /> and about the same depth, which has been cut through grass and earth into the underlying [[chalk]]. In his right hand the giant holds a knobbled [[Club (weapon)|club]] {{convert|120|ft|abbr=on}} in length.<ref name="sd" />
Its history cannot be traced back further than the late 17th century, making an origin during the [[British Iron Age|Celtic]], [[Roman Britain|Roman]] or even [[Early Medieval]] periods difficult to prove. Above and to the right of the Giant's head is an [[Earthworks (archaeology)|earthwork]] known as the "Trendle", or "Frying Pan". [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] writings refer to this location as "Trendle Hill", but make no mention of the giant, leading to the conclusion that it was probably only carved about 400 years ago. In contrast, the [[Uffington White Horse]]{{snd}} an unquestionably [[Prehistory|prehistoric]] hill figure on the [[North Wessex Downs|Berkshire Downs]]{{snd}} was noticed and recorded by medieval authors.<ref name="sd"/><ref name=hutchins>{{cite book |last=Hutchins |first=John |authorlink=John Hutchins (antiquary) |others=Robert Douch (Contributor) |title=The History and Antiquities of the County of Dorset |origyear=1742 |month= |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |year=1973 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers |location=Oxford |language= |isbn=0-87471-336-6 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= }}</ref>
In 2008, overgrowth forced a re-chalking of the giant,<ref>{{cite news |first= |last=BBC |authorlink=BBC |coauthors= |title= Sheep shortage hits Giant's look |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/dorset/7465329.stm |work= |publisher=''BBC'' |date=June 20, 2008 |accessdate=2008-06-20 }}</ref> with 17 tonnes of new chalk being poured in and tamped down by hand.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2008/sep/16/heritage.ruralaffairs|title=Volunteers restore historic giant of Cerne Abbas to his former glory|last=Morris|first=Steven|date=2008-09-16|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Newspapers|accessdate=2008-09-17}}</ref>
===Long Man of Wilmington=== [[File:Long Man of Wilmington.jpg|thumb|The [[Long Man of Wilmington]] seen from a distance]] {{main|Long Man of Wilmington}} The [[Long Man of Wilmington]] is a located on one of the steep slopes of Windover Hill, six miles (9.6 km) northwest of [[Eastbourne]]. The figure is 227 feet (69 m) tall and designed to look in proportion when viewed from below, and is shown holding two staves. The earliest record was made by the surveyor John Rowley in the year 1710. This drawing suggests that the original figure was a shadow or indentation in the grass, rather than the solid outline of a human figure. The staves were not depicted as a rake and scythe as was once thought, and the head was a helmet shape. Sir William Borrow's drawing of 1766 shows the figure holding a rake and a scythe, both shorter than the staves.<ref name="cope">''The Modern Antiquarian'', Julian Cope, Thorsons 1998</ref>
Before 1874, the Long Man's outline was only visible in certain light conditions as a different shade in the hillside grass, or after a light fall of snow. In that year an antiquarian marked out the outline with yellow bricks, later cemented together. It has been claimed that the 'restoration' process distorted the position of the feet, an assertion backed up by several who had been familiar with the figure before 1874, and also by later resistivity surveys.<ref name="Castleden2002">{{cite journal|url=http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/arch-285-1/dissemination/pdf/vol_140/Castleden.pdf |title=Shape-shifting: The changing outline of the Long Man of Wilmington |journal=Sussex Archaeological Collections |first=Rodney |last=Castleden |issue=140 |pages=83–95 |year=2002}}</ref> It has also been suggested that it removed the Long Man's genitalia, though there is no historical or archaeological evidence which supports that claim.<ref name="cope"/><ref>''The Unknown'', Issue Jan 1986</ref> A wide range of dates of origin have been proposed for the Long Man, but more recent archaeological work done by the [[University of Reading]] suggests that the figure dates from the 16th or 17th century AD.<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Derbyshire |title=Prehistoric Long Man is '16th century new boy' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1443003/Prehistoric-Long-Man-is-16th-century-new-boy.html |work=Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=2 October 2003 |accessdate=2009-02-08 }}</ref>
===Plymouth Hoe giants=== {{main|Plymouth Hoe}} Until the early 17th century large outline images of the two giants, perhaps [[Gog and Magog]] (or [[Goemagot|Goemagot and Corineus]]) had for a long time been cut into the turf of Plymouth Hoe exposing the white limestone beneath.<ref name="Gray 2003 153">{{Cite book | publisher = The Mint Press | isbn = 1-903356-32-6 | last = Gray | first = Todd | title = Lost Devon: Creation, Change and Destruction over 500 Years | location = Exeter, Devon | year = 2003 |pages = 153 }}</ref> An early and explicit reference was made to them by [[Richard Carew (antiquary)|Richard Carew]] in 1602.<ref>''The Survey of Cornwall'', text here:[http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext06/srvcr10.txt]. Note that Carew refers to Plymouth Hoe as "the Hawe at Plymmouth".</ref> At one time these figures were periodically re-cut and cleaned but no trace of them remains today.<ref name="Gray 2003 153"/><ref name="br4">{{cite book|last=Bracken|first=C. W.|title=A History of Plymouth and her Neighbours|publisher=Underhill|location=Plymouth|year=1931|pages=4}}</ref>
===Firle Corn=== {{main|Firle Corn}} [[Firle Corn]] in [[Firle]], [[Sussex]] is a nearly-lost hill figure whose existence can be seen by [[infrared photography]]. Now looking more like a small [[maize|ear of corn]] or a strange weapon than a human figure, there is a legend suggesting that a giant called Gill was once cut on this same hill and that he was considered an adversary of the Long Man of Wilmington not far away.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hows.org.uk/personal/hillfigs/lost/firle.htm|title=Firle Corn|author=|date=|work=hows.org.uk}}</ref> According to one story, the giant on Firle Beacon threw his hammer at the Wilmington giant and killed him, and that the figure on the hillside marks the place where his body fell.<ref>[http://www.themodernantiquarian.com/site/63/long_man_of_wilmington.html Scraps of Folklore Collected by John Philipps Emslie, C. S. Burne, ''Folklore'', Vol. 26, No. 2. (Jun. 30, 1915), pp. 153-170.]</ref>
===Homer Simpson=== As a publicity stunt for the opening of ''[[The Simpsons Movie]]'' on 16 July 2007, a giant [[Homer Simpson]] brandishing a [[doughnut]] was outlined in water-based [[biodegradable]] paint to the left of the Cerne Abbas Giant. This act angered local [[neopagans]], who pledged to perform "rain magic" to wash the figure away.<ref name="Wish for rain to wash away Homer">{{cite news|title=Wish for rain to wash away Homer|publisher=BBC News|date=2007-07-16|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/dorset/6901543.stm}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Hamblin|first1=Cory|title=Serket's Movies: Commentary and Trivia on 444 Movies|date=2009|publisher=Dorrance Publishing|isbn=9781434996053|page=327|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8074omXANY4C&pg=PA327|accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref>
==Horse figures== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2013}} There are 16 known white horse hill figures in the UK, or 17 including the painted one at [[Cleadon#Cleadon Hills|Cleadon Hills]].
The Luzley White Horse near [[Mossley]], cut in 1981, was neglected in 1992 after its creator died, but was not completely lost for some time.
Eight of the current white horses, and at least five of the lost figures, are in Wiltshire. The white horse is now generally considered a symbol of Wiltshire. An 1872 sketch of the Cherhill White Horse was later featured in the unofficial flag of Wiltshire, the [[Flag of Wiltshire#White Horse Flag|White Horse Flag]]. It was designed after its designer, Chrys Fear, decided the white horse symbol had a stronger connection to Wiltshire than the Great Bustard on the official flag. Additionally, for the third millennium, it was proposed that a white horse should feature on one of the surrounding hills in [[Devizes]] (It became the [[Devizes White Horse|Devizes Millennium White Horse]]). Smaller white horses now feature in Wiltshire, such as a replica of the Devizes White Horse in a Devizes primary school and two proposed white horses to feature on a roundabout in Marlborough (both towns already have larger white horses.) Liddington Hill near [[Swindon]] is the latest location in Wiltshire to have a proposed white horse, in the early 2000s, although the idea was abandoned.
===List of UK figures=== If the names of the horses are not capitalised, it is because these are an adopted nickname, rather than a general consensus on its name or the official name.
====Current figures==== {| class="wikitable" !Name !County !Cutting date |- | [[Uffington White Horse]] | [[Oxfordshire]] | 1000 BC |- | [[Long Man of Wilmington]] | [[East Sussex]] | 17th century? |- | [[Westbury White Horse]] | [[Wiltshire]] | 1778 |- | [[Cherhill White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1780 |- | [[Mormond Hill#The White Horse and the White Stag|Mormond White Horse]] | [[Aberdeenshire]] | 1790s |- | [[Marlborough White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1804 |- | [[Osmington White Horse]] | [[Dorset]] | 1808 |- | [[Alton Barnes White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1812 |- | [[Hackpen White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1838 |- | Woolbury White Horse | [[Hampshire]] | Before 1846 |- | [[Kilburn White Horse]] | [[North Yorkshire]] | 1857 |- | [[Broad Town White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1864 |- | [[Cleadon#Cleadon white horse|Cleadon White Horse]] | [[South Tyneside]] | Before 1887 |- | [[Litlington, East Sussex|Litlington]] White Horse | [[East Sussex]] | 1924 |- | [[Pewsey White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1937 |- | [[Devizes White Horse]] | Wiltshire | 1999 |- | [[Heeley]] White Horse | [[South Yorkshire]] | 2000 |- | [[Folkestone White Horse]] | [[Kent]] | 2003 |- | [[Lutterworth]] white horses | [[Leicestershire]] | 2012 |- | [[Devizes White Horse#Replica|Nursteed School white horse, Devizes]] | [[Wiltshire]] | 2012 |- | [[Beverley Racecourse]] white horses | [[East Riding of Yorkshire|East Riding]] | 2010s |- | Black Horse of Bush Howe | [[Cumbria]] | ? <small>(may be a natural figure)</small> |}

===List of international figures=== If the names of the horses are not capitalised, it is because these are an adopted nickname, rather than a general consensus on its name or the official name. {| class="wikitable" !Name !Location !Cut !Lost |- | Bloemfontein White Horse | [[Bloemfontein]], [[South Africa]] | Before 1932 | N/A |- | Cockington Green white horse | Cockington Green, [[Canberra]], [[Australia]] | 20th or 21st century | N/A |- | Georgia white horse | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States | 20th or 21st century | N/A |- | Juárez White Horse | [[Ciudad Juárez]], [[Mexico]] | Unknown | N/A |- | Riff Country horse | [[Iourdanan]], [[Morocco]] | Unknown | Unknown |- | [[Spis Castle]] Celtic Horse | [[Žehra]], [[Slovakia]] | 2000s | N/A |- | Tunis Horses | [[Tunis]], [[Tunisia]] | Unknown | N/A |- | [[Waimate]] White Horse | [[Waimate]], [[New Zealand]] | Late 1960s | N/A |- |} The horses in Cockington Green, Georgia and Juárez are all based on the style of or direct copies of the Uffington White Horse.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
==Lost figures== Since hill figures must be maintained by the removal of regrown turf, only those that motivate the local populace to look after them survive. Surviving ancient figures all have an associated fair or ceremony that involves maintaining them.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}}
Unmaintained figures gradually fade away.<ref name="hows">{{cite web|last = Hows|first=Mark|title=Lost Figures|work=Hillfigure site|url=http://www.hows.org.uk/personal/hillfigs/lost/lostfig.htm|accessdate = 2014-01-20}}</ref> [[Firle Corn]] at [[Firle Beacon]], [[Sussex]] could be a lost figure. Its existence is suggested by [[infrared photography]]. If it is a lost figure, its age is uncertain, and unlikely [[Prehistory|prehistoric]] in origin, as only one figure in the UK has been shown to be of this age, the [[Uffington White Horse]].{{citation needed|date=February 2013}}
There have been horses at Devizes and [[Pewsey]], both in Wiltshire, that have been lost but replaced by new ones in the 20th century.<ref name="hows"/>
==Influence on other art forms== The white horses of Wiltshire, of which there are currently nine, have inspired other sculptures in the county. Julive Livsey's sculpture ''White Horse Pacified'' (1987) in Shaw, [[Swindon]] was inspired by the white horses.<ref>[http://www.swindonadvertiser.co.uk/news/10638539.Staying_in_the_public_eye/ Staying in the public eye (From Swindon Advertiser)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Furthermore, Charlotte Moreton created the steel sculpture ''White Horse'' (2010) for Solstice Park, [[Amesbury]], taking influence from the white horses.<ref>{{cite web|title=SOLSTICE PARK SCULPTURES|url=http://www.solsticepark.com/files/2713/9284/1982/solstice-park-sculptures-leaflet-Nov-2013.pdf|website=Solsticepark.com|accessdate=August 29, 2015}}</ref> A roundabout in Westbury, which features views of Westbury White Horse, features a canvas of the horse, with the horse also featuring in a mosaic in the town. When the county was choosing an [[Flag of Wiltshire|official flag]] in 2006–07, a suggested nominee was the "[[Flag of England|White Horse Flag]]", featuring Cherhill White Horse. The Town Flag of [[Pewsey]], registered in September 2014, features the Pewsey White Horse at its centre.

{{advert|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox publisher | name = Inkshares | image = Inkshares_Logo.png | caption = | parent = | status = | traded_as = | predecessor = | founded = 2013 | founders = Thaddeus Woodman, Lawrence Levitsky, Adam Gomolin, and Jeremy Thomas | successor = | country = United States | headquarters = Oakland, California | distribution = [[Ingram Content Group|Ingram Publisher Services]] | keypeople = | publications = Books | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | owner = | numemployees = | website = {{URL|https://www.inkshares.com}} }}
'''Inkshares''' is a publishing and literary [[Collective rights management|rights-management]] platform founded in 2013. It is an open platform with a community of over 100,000 authors and readers. Authors post partial manuscripts which are sorted based on reader interest. Selected manuscripts are edited by Inkshares for [[publishing]] in North America, sale into foreign territories, and development in television and film.
Inkshares investors include [[Ingram Ventures]], [[Indicator Ventures]], and prominent angels in the media and entertainment space. Inkshares has strategic relationships with Ingram for North American [[book distribution]] and [[The United Talented Agency]] for representation and packaging in television and film.
Inkshares has been called “the future of publishing” by ''The Wall Street Journal''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/02/07/star-wars-writer-gary-whitta-journeys-to-the-future-of-publishing/|title=‘Star Wars’ Writer Gary Whitta Journeys to the Future of Publishing|last=Calia|first=Michael|date=2015-02-07|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebookseller.com/futurebook/meet-inkshares-studio-books-making-waves-london-book-fair-511001|title=Meet Inkshares, the "studio for books" hoping to conquer London Book Fair {{!}} The Bookseller|website=www.thebookseller.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref>
== Founding ==
=== Founders and Founding === Inkshares was founded in 2013 by Thaddeus Woodman, Lawrence Levitsky, Adam Gomolin, and Jeremy Thomas. The original notion for Inkshares was developed by Woodman, whose parents founded a successful computer-book publishing company called Ventana Press in the 1990s. Spurred by the success of Kickstarter and the promise of the equity crowdfunding provisions of the JOBS Act, Woodman initially sought to create an equity crowdfunding portal for books.
Woodman discussed the concept with Levitsky, a former founding vice president of RealNetworks, who had worked at Ventana Press with Woodman’s parents after running Microsoft Press. Levitsky introduced Woodman to Gomolin, a securities attorney and represented screenwriter. After the three raised a small $250k friend-and-family-round in late 2013, they hired Thomas as a co-founder and Chief Technical Officer.
=== Funding Rounds === Woodman, Gomolin, and Levitsky raised a $250k friends-and-family round in late 2013. In the summer of 2014, Inkshares raised its first seed round with participation from Ingram Ventures (the venture arm of the largest book distributor in the world) and Indicator Ventures. The round also had participation from prominent publishing angels including Nion McEvoy, CEO of Chronicle Books.
Inkshares raised follow-on seed rounds in 2016 and 2017, including participation from 555 Capital and prominent Hollywood angels including Warner Brothers president of film and chief creative officer Greg Silverman.
=== Early Premise and Formation === The original notion presented by Woodman was to create a platform akin to “Kickstarter meets Random House” but complete with the ability to sell shares in a book so that readers could participate in the revenue stream for titles. At the time, while the Jobs Act had directed the SEC to create “equity crowdfunding,” the SEC had yet to promulgate rules, ultimately doing so multiple years late. Inkshares initially launched without the equity component, receiving extensive press in outlets including Fast Company<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3027396/can-a-startup-help-publishers-cut-out-twitter-facebook-and-flipboard|title=Can A Startup Help Publishers Cut Out Twitter, Facebook, And Flipboard?|date=2014-03-07|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-US}}</ref> and Publishers Weekly.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/63694-inkshares-looks-to-marry-the-old-with-the-new.html|title=Inkshares Looks to Marry the Old with the New|work=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en}}</ref>
== Evolution of Inkshares ==
=== Evolution of Funding Model === The original Inkshares model was premised on donations. Inkshares generated funding goals based on page length and projected design and print costs, and patrons could donate as much as they would like. Multiple successful projects were funded during this period, including ''The Astronaut Instruction Manual'' and ''The Show''.
Beginning in 2015, Thomas, Woodman, and Gomolin moved the model from donations to pre-orders, starkly limiting the amount any one person could donate to a project. The first project to fund under this new model was ''Abomination'', the debut novel of Gary Whitta, screenwriter of The Book of Eli and Star Wars: Rogue One. Though this “pre-order” model made it harder for books to fund, Thomas, Woodman, and Gomolin believed that it would stop the type of vanity publishing that frequently occurred on Kickstarter and help map to genuine reader interest. During this period, Levitsky left the company to pursue his own imprint.
In late 2016, Inkshares began measuring non-monetary engagement such as shares, likes, and total times spent by readers on selected manuscripts. The first book published on the basis of engagement rather than pre-orders was ''Devil’s Call'' by J. Danielle Dorn.
=== Evolution of Rights Management === By early 2016, Inkshares was experiencing significant growth in not just publishing but rights management. This had always been a significant focus for Gomolin, who had been represented in Hollywood and as Inkshares general counsel had written rights-management contracts into Inkshares’ first contracts in 2014. In 2015, Inkshares sold the streaming television rights for Filip Syta’s ''The Show'' to Blackpills in a large deal publicized by Business Insider.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/filip-syta-the-show-google-film-movie-2016-3?r=UK&IR=T|title=They're going to make a movie of the Google employee's novel which describes all the sex and drugs at a fictional search ad company|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en}}</ref> Immediately following this, Inkshares sold the audiobook rights to Penguin Random House in a six-figure deal that was rumoured to be the largest debut-author audio deal of the year. Later that year, Inkshares would sell Mike Mongo’s ''The Astronaut Instruction Manual'' to Legendary Entertainment<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/astronaut-instruction-manual-heading-tv-910221|title='Astronaut Instruction Manual' Heading to TV From Legendary, Matt Tolmach (Exclusive)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en}}</ref> and J-F Dubeau’s ''A God in the Shed'' to Skydance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tracking-board.com/skydance-lands-hot-manuscript-a-god-in-the-shed-from-j-f-dubeau-with-akiva-goldsman-set-to-produce-exclusive/|title=Skydance Lands Hot Manuscript "A God In The Shed" from J.F. Dubeau with Akiva Goldsman Set To Produce (EXCLUSIVE)|date=2016-10-06|work=The Tracking Board|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Inkshares would follow these deals with myriad more sales in 2017, including the seven-figure deal for Tal Klein’s ''The Punch Escrow'', now in development at Lionsgate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/lionsgate-lands-sci-fi-story-punch-escrow-991810|title=Lionsgate in Talks to Pick Up Sci-Fi Story 'The Punch Escrow'|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en}}</ref>

'''James Walter Miller''' (1890–1950) was an American citizen and an alleged asset of the San Francisco Office of the [[KGB]] from 1943 to 1945. Miller worked in the [[United States Government]] wartime mail censorship office. Miller was allegedly [[Agent handling#Recruitment|recruited]] into [[espionage]] for the [[Soviet Union]] by [[Isaac Folkoff]] of the [[Communist Party of the United States of America]] (CPUSA). His cover name was "Vague".
Born '''Milawski''' in [[Russia]], he changed his name to Miller after coming to the United States in 1907. He became a member of the Communist Party in Los Angeles. Miller was associated with Victor Milo while in the California Communist Party. Miller at one time worked for ''Russky Golos'' ''(Russian Voice)'', the [[American-Russian Institute]], and ''[[People's World]]''.
Miller was one of Folkoff's most valuable agents. Miller spoke Russian, and was a Russian-language translator with the financial and trade section of the U.S. government wartime mail censorship office. Miller worked in an area of considerable interest to Soviet intelligence. In 1943 Folkoff passed on to the KGB material from Miller on several occasions. San Francisco ''Rezident'' [[Grigory Kheifets]] attested to Miller's ''bone fides'' in a Venona decrypt, putting to rest reservations from Moscow that because of Miller's eagerness, he may be a double agent.
Miller began passing information to [[Harrison George]] at the ''People's World''. In 1943 Miller reported the Mail Censor's office found secret writing in a letter that a Naval [[GRU]] Officer sent to Moscow. In 1944 Miller came to the attention of the [[FBI]] in the "Comintern Apparatus" investigation. The FBI witnessed Miller meeting Kheifets at least six times in early 1944. Miller was eventually forced out of the government office. He died in 1950.
==Venona==
James Walter Miller is referenced in the following [[Venona project]] decryptions:
*450 KGB San Francisco to Moscow, 1 November 1943 *472 KGB San Francisco to Moscow, 9 November 1943 *511 KGB San Francisco to Moscow, 7 December 1943 *539 KGB San Francisco to Moscow, 31 December 1943 *147 San Francisco to Moscow, 27 March 1944 *68 KGB San Francisco to Moscow, 27 February 1945
==References== *John Earl Haynes and Harvey Klehr, ''Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America'', Yale University Press (1999), pgs. 207, 228–229.

[[File:2014 Gini Index World Map, income inequality distribution by country per World Bank.svg|thumb|upright=2.1|Countries' income inequality (2014) according to their Gini coefficients measured in percent: red = higher than average, green = lower than average inequality.]] This is a '''list of countries or dependencies by [[income inequality metrics]]''', including [[Gini coefficient]]s. The Gini coefficient is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 corresponds with perfect equality (where everyone has the same income) and 1 corresponds with perfect inequality (where one person has all the income{{mdash}}and everyone else has zero income). Income distribution can vary greatly from wealth distribution in a country (see [[List of countries by distribution of wealth]]). Income from [[black market]] economic activity is not included and is the subject of current economic research.[http://www.gler.it/gler_XV_1/Odoardi.pdf Underground economy and income inequality: two connected aspects in the oncoming context of Italian federalism] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209211941/http://www.gler.it/gler_XV_1/Odoardi.pdf |date=2012-02-09 }}. This article is a partial list of journalists killed and missing during the [[Vietnam War]]. The press freedom organization [[Reporters Without Borders]] tallied 63 journalists who died over a 20-year period ending in 1975 while covering the [[Vietnam War]] with the caveat that media workers were not typically counted at the time.<ref name=witness>{{cite book|first1=Fay |last1=Anderson |first2=Richard |last2=Trembath |title=Witnesses To War: The History Of Australian Conflict Reporting |place=Melbourne |publisher=Melbourne University Publishing |year=2011 |pages=240–241 |accessdate=2013-11-06 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GpVkJRvmlqsC}}</ref><ref name=ajr>{{cite news|title=Dangerous assignment |publisher=American Journalism Review |date= December–January 2006 |accessdate=2013-11-06 |url=http://www.ajr.org/article.asp?id=4003}}</ref>
==List== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year and date killed/missing !! Surname, First name(s) !! Nationality !! Agency !! [[Military operation|Operation]]/Battle Name !! Location !! Circumstances of loss !! Burial |- |1965 || Tran, Pham || North Vietnamese || [[Nhân Dân]] || || Vietnam || Killed when his unit engaged US and [[ARVN]] forces<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thejournalistsmemorial.rsf.org/?pays_deces=22&date_mini=1960&date_maxi=1969&debut_articles_recents=60&id_article=1546 |title=Tranh Pham|work=The Journalists Memorial|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1965, May 27 || Van Thiel, Pieter || American || Freelancer || || Vietnam, Mekong Delta || Captured by the [[Vietcong]] during an ARVN attack, he was tortured then executed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newseum.org/scripts/Journalist/Detail.asp?PhotoID=653 |title=Van Thiel, Pieter|work=Newseum.org|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1965, September 16 || Rose, Jerry || American || Freelancer || || Vietnam || Killed when the plane he was travelling in crashed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newseum.org/scripts/Journalist/Detail.asp?PhotoID=634 |title=Rose, Jerry|work=Newseum.org|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1965, October 2 || Kolenberg, Bernard || American || [[Associated Press]] || || Vietnam || Killed when the [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|A-1]] he was travelling in collided with another A-1 and crashed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newseum.org/scripts/Journalist/Detail.asp?PhotoID=600 |title=Kolenberg, Bernard|work=Newseum.org|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1965, October 10 || Huynh, Thanh My || South Vietnamese || Associated Press || || Vietnam, [[Can Tho]] || Wounded while photographing an engagement between the [[Vietcong]] and [[Vietnamese Rangers]], he was awaiting evacuation when the Vietcong overran the landing zone and killed all the wounded<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitaljournalist.org/issue9711/req32.htm |title=Requiem - Huynh Thanh My|work=The Digital Journalist|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1965, November 4 || [[Dickey Chapelle|Chapelle, Dickey]] || American || || [[Operation Black Ferret]] || Vietnam, [[Quang Ngai Province]] || Killed while on patrol with a [[United States Marine Corps]] unit when a landmine fragment severed her carotid artery.<ref>{{cite book|last=Johnson|first=Charles|title=U.S. Marines in Vietnam: The Landing and the Buildup, 1965 (Marine Corps Vietnam Operational Historical Series)|publisher=Marine Corps Association|year=1978|isbn=978-0-89839-259-3|pages=93–96}}</ref>|| |- |1966, February 14 || Chellappah, Charles || Singaporean || Associated Press || || Vietnam, || Killed by a claymore mine while on patrol with US forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newseum.org/scripts/Journalist/Detail.asp?PhotoID=736 |title=Chellappah, Charles|work=Newseum.org|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref><ref name=singaporeans>{{cite news|author=Toh Yong Chuan |title=Eye on Singapore: The story of Charles, Terry and Sam |newspaper=Straits Times |date=August 10, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-06 |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/singapore/story/eye-singapore-the-story-charles-terry-and-sam-20130810}}</ref>|| |- |1966, May 21 || Castan, Sam || American || [[Look (American magazine)|Look magazine]] || || Vietnam, [[Landing Zone Hereford]] || Killed by mortar fire with a unit of the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)|1st Cavalry Division]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newseum.org/scripts/Journalist/Detail.asp?PhotoID=560 |title=Castan, Sam|work=Newseum.org|accessdate=7 May 2013}}</ref>|| |- |1967, February 21 || [[Bernard B. [[Temple University Beasley School of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Mary Mona Lisi''' (born 1950) is a [[United States federal judge|Senior United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island]]. == Early life and education == Born in [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]], [[Rhode Island]], Lisi earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1972 from the [[University of Rhode Island]] and a [[Juris Doctor]] in 1977 from [[Temple University Beasley School of Law]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/lisi-mary-m.|title=Lisi, Mary M. - Federal Judicial Center|publisher=}} == Professional career == Lisi began her career as an assistant public defender in the Rhode Island Public Defender's Office, where she worked from 1977 until 1981. She then worked as an assistant child advocate for the Office of the Child Advocate for the State of Rhode Island from 1981 until 1982. Lisi concurrently worked in private legal practice from 1981 until 1982, when she took a job as Director of the Court Appointed Special Advocate Program for the Rhode Island Family Court. She held that job from 1982 until 1987. Lisi then became Deputy Disciplinary Counsel for the [[Rhode Island Supreme Court]] from 1988 until 1990 and Chief Disciplinary Counsel for the Rhode Island Supreme Court from 1990 until 1994, when she was tapped for a seat on the federal bench. == Federal judicial service == On the recommendation of United States Senator [[Claiborne Pell]], Lisi was nominated by President Bill Clinton on January 27, 1994 to a seat vacated by [[Francis Joseph Boyle]] as Boyle assumed [[senior status]]. The [[United States Senate]] confirmed Lisi in a voice vote on May 6, 1994. Lisi was chief judge of her court from 2006 to 2013. She assumed [[senior status]] on October 1, 2015. == References == {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *[https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/lisi-mary-m. {{featured article}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Dwayne Jones in Car.jpg|thumb|Dwayne Jones sitting in a car's driver seat]] '''Dwayne Jones''' was a Jamaican 16-year-old who was killed by a [[mobbing|violent mob]] in [[Montego Bay]] in 2013, after he attended a dance party dressed in women's clothing.{{efn|While some media commentators describe Jones as [[transgender]],<ref name="PinkNewsVigil"/><ref name="McFadden"/> his best friend described him using male pronouns,<ref name="McFadden"/> and so other sources refer to him as a [[cross-dressing|cross-dresser]]<ref name="Gleaner28"/> or [[gender variance|gender non-conforming]].<ref name="J-FLAG"/>}} The incident attracted national and international media attention and brought increased scrutiny to the status of [[LGBT rights in Jamaica]].
Perceived as [[effeminancy|effeminate]], Jones was [[bullying|bullied]] in school and, at the age of 14, was forced out of his family home by his father. He moved into a derelict house in Montego Bay with [[transgender]] friends. On the evening of 21 July 2013, they went to the [[Irwin, Jamaica|Irwin]] area of the city and attended a dance party. When some men at the party discovered that the [[cross-dressing]] Jones was not a woman, they confronted and attacked him. Jones was beaten, stabbed, shot, and run over with a car; he died in the early hours of the morning. Police investigated the murder but did not arrest or charge anyone for the crime, which remains unsolved.
The event made newspaper headlines in Jamaica and was also the subject of reporting in both the United Kingdom and the United States. While voices on social media accused Jones of provoking his killers by cross-dressing in public, the murder was condemned by Jamaican educators and the country's [[Cabinet of Jamaica|Justice Minister]]. In the wake of the attack, both domestic and international organisations devoted to [[LGBT rights by country|LGBT rights]] and [[human rights]] – among them [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Jamaicans for Justice]], and the [[J-FLAG|Jamaica Forum for Lesbians, All-Sexuals & Gays]] – asked the Jamaican authorities for a proper investigation and legal recognition of LGBT rights on the island.
==Background== ===Jones' biography=== [[File:Montego Bay Photo D Ramey Logan.jpg|thumb|right|View of Montego Bay from the hillside, where Jones was squatting]]
Raised in an impoverished slum in [[Montego Bay]], a city in northwest Jamaica, Jones faced bullying at high school from students who perceived his behaviour as [[effeminacy|effeminate]].<ref name="McFadden">{{cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/jamaica-transgender-teen-murdered-mob|title=In Jamaica, transgender teen killed by mob|work=[[Associated Press]]|author=McFadden, David|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=11 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103213141/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/jamaica-transgender-teen-murdered-mob|archivedate=3 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Wills">{{cite news|url=http://www.webpronews.com/transgender-teen-dwayne-jones-murdered-by-mob-2013-08|title=Transgender Teen Dwayne Jones Murdered by Mob|publisher=Web Pro News|author=Wills, Courtney|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=11 August 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MLxS4Ckk?url=http://www.webpronews.com/transgender-teen-dwayne-jones-murdered-by-mob-2013-08|archivedate=3 January 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> When Jones was 14, his father ejected him from the family home and encouraged neighbours to chase him out of the neighbourhood.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> After a period sleeping in bushes and on beaches, he began [[squatting]] in a derelict house in the hills above Montego Bay with two transgender friends, Keke and Khloe, both 23 at the time of Jones' death.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> Jones was known among friends as "Gully Queen",<ref name="McFadden"/> a reference to the storm drainage systems in which many homeless LGBT Jamaicans live.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/world/2014/07/31/watch-go-underground-jamaicas-gully-queens|title=WATCH: Go Underground with Jamaica's 'Gully Queens'|website=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|Advocate]]|date=31 July 2014|accessdate=5 July 2015|author=Senzee, Thom|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnrysiKo?url=http://www.advocate.com/world/2014/07/31/watch-go-underground-jamaicas-gully-queens|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Friends noted that Jones desired to become a teacher or to work in the [[Tourism in Jamaica|tourist industry]].<ref name="Quinn">{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/08/11/homophobia_a_way_of_life_in_jamaica.html|title=Homophobia a way of life in Jamaica|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|author=Quinn, Jennifer|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=11 August 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6MLxmvhJe?url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/08/11/homophobia_a_way_of_life_in_jamaica.html|archivedate=3 January 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> He also wanted to become a performer like the American pop star [[Lady Gaga]], and had won a local dancing competition.<ref name="McFadden"/> Khloe described him as "a diva" who was "always very feisty and joking around".<ref name="McFadden"/>
===Anti-LGBT sentiment in Jamaica=== In 2006, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine said that Jamaica may be the most [[homophobia|homophobic]] country in the world.<ref>{{cite web|author=Padgett, Tim|title=The Most Homophobic Place on Earth?|date=12 April 2006|website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1182991,00.html|accessdate=19 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160101043423/http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1182991%2C00.html|archivedate=1 January 2016|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The country's [[LGBT rights in Jamaica#Laws, policies, and the Jamaican constitution|laws criminalising same-sex activity]] between males were introduced in 1864, during the [[Colony of Jamaica|British colonial administration]]. According to the [[Sexual Offences Act of 2009]], any man convicted under these laws must register as a [[sex offender]].<ref name="IBTimes"/><ref name="HRWReport"/> These laws have been cited as contributing to wider homophobic attitudes among the Jamaican populace,<ref name="HRWReport"/> including the view that gay people are criminals regardless of whether or not they have committed any criminal act.<ref name="IBTimes"/> Anti-LGBT perspectives have been furthered by the island's conservative Christian churches.<ref name="IBTimes"/> Many [[reggae]] and [[dancehall]] songs, among them [[Buju Banton]]'s "Boom Bye Bye", call for the killing of gays.<ref name="IBTimes"/> Writing for the ''[[International Business Times]]'' in the summer of 2013, the journalist Palash Gosh noted that while Jamaica was "awash in crime and violence, gays and lesbians are particularly prominent targets of wanton brutality."<ref name="IBTimes"/> In the mid-2000s, two of Jamaica's best-known LGBT rights activists, [[Brian Williamson]] and [[Lenford Harvey|Steve Harvey]], were murdered.<ref name="IBTimes"/> In the summer of 2013, [[Human Rights Watch]] carried out five weeks of fieldwork among Jamaica's LGBT community, reporting that over half of those interviewed had experienced violence as a result of their sexual orientation or gender identity, sometimes on more than one occasion.<ref name="HRWReport"/>
==Murder== On the evening of 21 July 2013 – when Jones was 16 – he dressed in female clothing and attended a dance party with Keke and Khloe called Henessey Sundays, held at a bar in the [[Irwin, Jamaica|Irwin]] area.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/><ref name="IrieFM">{{cite news|url=http://www.iriefm.net/news/headline/cross-dressing-teen-killed-mob|title=Cross dressing teen killed by mob|publisher=Irie FM|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=22 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LCdlc9nP?url=http://www.iriefm.net/news/headline/cross-dressing-teen-killed-mob|archivedate=17 November 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="LGBTNation">{{cite news|url=http://www.lgbtqnation.com/2013/07/cross-dressing-gay-teen-hacked-stabbed-to-death-by-jamaican-mob/|title=Cross-dressing gay teen hacked, stabbed to death by Jamaican mob|publisher=LGBTQ Nation|author=Littauer, Dan|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=23 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnsazdVb?url=http://www.lgbtqnation.com/2013/07/cross-dressing-gay-teen-hacked-stabbed-to-death-by-jamaican-mob/|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> They arrived by taxi at around 2 am.<ref name="Wills"/> Jones [[passing (gender)|passed]] as a girl at the party, and several males danced with him.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> Although he initially kept his biological sex a secret from others at the party, fearing [[homophobia|homophobic]] persecution, he revealed his identity to a girl with whom he had previously been to church.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> The girl informed her male friends, who accosted him outside the venue, demanding to know, "Are you a woman or a man?"<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> One of the men used a lantern to examine Jones' feet, claiming that they were too large to be those of a biological woman.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> Discovering his sex, they started calling him "[[batty boy]]" and other homophobic epithets.<ref name="McFadden"/> Khloe tried to get him to avoid confrontation, whispering in his ear, "Walk with me, walk with me", but Jones refused, instead insisting to those assembled that he was female.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/>
When someone pulled on Jones' bra strap, he ran away, and the crowd pursued and attacked him further down the road. He was beaten, stabbed, shot and run over by a car. He slipped in and out of consciousness for two hours before another attack finally killed him.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> There were no reports of anyone trying to help him during the altercation.<ref name="LGBTNation"/> Khloe was also attacked and almost raped, but escaped by hiding first in a church and then in neighbouring woods.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/> Khloe commented, "When I saw Dwayne's body, I started shaking and crying. It was horrible."<ref name="McFadden"/> Police arrived at the scene at 5 am to find the body dumped in bushes along Orange Main Road.<ref name="IrieFM"/><ref name="LGBTNation"/><ref name="Gleaner24"/> They launched an investigation into the homicide, inviting friends and family of the victim to contact them.<ref name="Gleaner23">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/latest/article.php?id=46680|title=Police Probe St James Teen Murder|newspaper=[[The Gleaner (newspaper)|The Gleaner]]|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=23 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnuivTIo?url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/power/46680|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Jones' family declined to claim the body, and his father refused to talk to the press about the incident.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Wills"/>
On 14 August, Deputy Superintendent of Police Steve Brown announced that fourteen statements had been collected and that the investigation was progressing.<ref name="JamaicaObserver">{{cite news|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Police--Arrest-soon-in-cross-dresser-s-death_14870714|title=Police: Arrest soon in cross-dresser's death|newspaper=[[The Jamaica Observer]]|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=14 August 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnvGKcrf?url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Police--Arrest-soon-in-cross-dresser-s-death_14870714|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> In October 2013, a group of men set fire to the place in which Jones had lived as a squatter, forcing its four occupants to flee, in what was also believed to be an [[Violence against LGBT people|anti-LGBT hate crime]].<ref name="PinkNewsArson">{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/10/11/jamaica-murdered-transgender-teens-house-firebombed/|title=Jamaica: Murdered transgender teen's house firebombed|author=Roberts, Scott|publisher=[[PinkNews]]|accessdate=11 October 2013|date=11 October 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Znz6TwN7?url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/10/11/jamaica-murdered-transgender-teens-house-firebombed/|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Everald Morgan, an officer at the St James Public Health Department, requested that police provide protection for the four youths made homeless by the arson attack, but they declined to do so.<ref name="PinkNewsArson"/> Meanwhile, a charity named Dwayne's House was set up in Jones' memory to aid homeless LGBT youth in Jamaica.<ref name="PinkNewsLawyer">{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2014/05/19/lawyer-jamaican-prime-minister-has-betrayed-gay-voters-by-refusing-to-lift-buggery-law/|title=Lawyer: Jamaican Prime Minister has betrayed gay voters by refusing to lift buggery law|date=19 May 2014|publisher=PinkNews|author=Roberts, Scott|accessdate=19 May 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Znwg8GrS?url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2014/05/19/lawyer-jamaican-prime-minister-has-betrayed-gay-voters-by-refusing-to-lift-buggery-law/|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/lesterfeder/how-jamaicas-sodomy-laws-drive-gay-teens-into-the-sewers-of#.qgABrRoR8R|title=Why Some LGBT Youths in Jamaica Are Forced to Call a Sewer Home|author=Feder, J. Lester|website=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=18 December 2013|accessdate=5 July 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnxSwU0C?url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/lesterfeder/how-jamaicas-sodomy-laws-drive-gay-teens-into-the-sewers-of|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> {{as of|2014|May}}, however, no one had been arrested or charged,<ref name="PinkNewsLawyer"/> and in August 2015 the crime was still considered unsolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/10/jamaica-first-gay-pride-celebration-symbol-change|title=Jamaica's first public gay pride event a symbol of change: 'It felt liberating'|date=10 August 2015|website=[[The Guardian]]|author=Davis, Nick|accessdate=19 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112205845/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/10/jamaica-first-gay-pride-celebration-symbol-change|archivedate=12 January 2016}}</ref>
==Reaction==
===In Jamaica=== Jones' murder made headline news across Jamaica.<ref name="McFadden"/> Jamaica's Justice Minister, Senator [[Mark Golding]], condemned the killing and called for an end to "depraved acts of violence" in Jamaica.<ref name="JamaicaObserver"/> He added that "all well-thinking Jamaicans" should embrace "the principle of respect for the basic human rights of all persons" and express tolerance towards minority groups such as the LGBT community.<ref name="IBTimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/boom-bye-bye-murder-cross-dresser-lifts-lid-jamaicas-violent-homophobia-1370173|title=Boom Bye Bye: Murder of Cross-Dresser Lifts Lid on Jamaica's Violent Homophobia|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|author=Ghosh, Palash|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=2 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140211045826/http://www.ibtimes.com/boom-bye-bye-murder-cross-dresser-lifts-lid-jamaicas-violent-homophobia-1370173|archivedate=11 February 2014}}</ref> Annie Paul, the publications officer of the Jamaican campus of the [[University of the West Indies]] (UWI), stated that on the basis of comments provided on social media, she thought that most Jamaicans believed that Jones provoked his own murder by cross-dressing within a society that did not tolerate such behaviour.<ref name="McFadden"/><ref name="Roberts"/> Newton D. Duncan, the UWI Professor of Paediatric Surgery, similarly noted that the "overwhelming majority" of Jamaicans believed that cross-dressers are homosexuals and deserve punishment. He added that this was a common misconception, because the majority of cross-dressers were heterosexual. He condemned the attack and compared it to the [[Lynching in the United States|lynching]] of an [[African Americans|African-American]] man in [[Harper Lee]]'s novel ''[[To Kill a Mockingbird]]'', drawing links between the anti-LGBT violence of Jamaica and the anti-black violence of the mid-20th century United States.<ref name="Duncan">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130901/focus/focus4.html|title=To Kill a Cross-Dresser - Jamaica Flirts with Jim Crow|newspaper=The Gleaner|author=Duncan, Newton D.|accessdate=11 October 2013|date=1 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705230144/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130901/focus/focus4.html|archivedate=July 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Portia Miller Shoot.Jpeg|left|thumb|150px|Domestic and foreign human rights organisations called on then Prime Minister [[Portia Simpson-Miller]] to improve LGBT rights in Jamaica, as she had promised during her election campaign.<ref name="IBTimes"/><ref name="PinkNewsArson"/><ref name="Martinez">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130727/news/news3.html|title=JFJ Condemns Mob Killing of Cross-Dresser|newspaper=The Gleaner|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=27 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705231423/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130727/news/news3.html|archivedate=5 July 2015}}</ref>]]
Writing in the Jamaican broadsheet ''[[The Gleaner (newspaper)|The Gleaner]]'', Carolyn Cooper, Professor of Literary and Cultural Studies at UWI, condemned the group who committed Jones' murder. She blamed their behaviour on the selective use of the [[Bible]], noting that while many Jamaicans embrace those Biblical passages which [[The Bible and homosexuality|condemn same-sex sexual activity and cross-dressing]], they are themselves typically guilty of many other Biblical sins, such as [[adultery]] and [[murder]].<ref name="Cooper">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130804/cleisure/cleisure3.html|title=Dressed for Murder|newspaper=The Gleaner|author=Cooper, Carolyn|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=4 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222191011/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130804/cleisure/cleisure3.html|archivedate=22 December 2015}}</ref> She commented that Jones had been killed just for being himself and expressed the hope that his killers face legal prosecution for their crime.<ref name="Cooper"/> The following week she published a follow-up article in which she responded to several emails that she had received which claimed that the real victims of the scenario were the men whom Jones deceived when he was dancing with them. She reiterated her condemnation of Jones' killers, remarking that rather than retaliating violently, they should have brushed it off with a humorous comment.<ref name="Cooper2">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130811/cleisure/cleisure3.html|title=Sexual Falsehood Top to Bottom|newspaper=The Gleaner|author=Cooper, Carolyn|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=11 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222205646/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130811/cleisure/cleisure3.html|archivedate=22 December 2015}}</ref>
Jaevion Nelson, an [[HIV/AIDS]] campaigner and human rights advocate, also published an article on the subject in ''The Gleaner''. He noted that his initial reaction was to question why Jones had gone to the dance party and why he was not satisfied in attending Jamaica's [[Underground culture|underground]] gay parties. He added that he had subsequently realised that adopting this viewpoint was rooted in "the culture of violence" by which a [[victim blaming|victim is blamed]] for what happened to them. He called on Jamaicans to be tolerant of LGBT individuals, and to focus on "rebuilding this great nation on the principles of inclusivity, love, equality and respect with no distinctions whatsoever".<ref name="Nelson">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130801/cleisure/cleisure3.html|title=Make Space for Pariahs|newspaper=The Gleaner|author=Nelson, Jaevion|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=1 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802004039/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130801/cleisure/cleisure3.html|archivedate=2 August 2013}}</ref> Also in ''The Gleaner'', Sheila Veléz Martínez, a law professor at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], condemned the murder as "alarming evidence" of the high rates of homophobia in Jamaican society.<ref name="Martinez2">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130813/cleisure/cleisure3.html|title=Gov't Shouldn't Let Dwayne Jones' Death Go in Vain|newspaper=The Gleaner|author=Veléz Martínez, Sheila|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=13 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705231423/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20130727/news/news3.html|archivedate=5 July 2015}}</ref>
On 25 July, the [[J-FLAG|Jamaica Forum for Lesbians, All-Sexuals & Gays]] (J-FLAG), an LGBT rights organisation, issued a public statement expressing their "deep concern" regarding the case, and offering their condolences to Jones' friends and family. They encouraged local people to aid the police in locating the perpetrators of the attack, which they asserted was an affront to Jamaica's democracy.<ref name="J-FLAG">{{cite news|url=http://www.jflag.org/2013/07/violence-against-lgbt-people-is-an-affront-to-democracy/|title=Violence is an Affront to Democracy|publisher=Jamaica Forum for Lesbians, All-Sexuals & Gays|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=23 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LCeQaWv7?url=http://www.jflag.org/2013/07/violence-against-lgbt-people-is-an-affront-to-democracy/|archivedate=17 November 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Gleaner24">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/latest/article.php?id=46697|title=J-FLAG Condemns Mob Killing of Alleged MoBay Cross-Dresser|newspaper=The Gleaner|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=24 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnuEKr1x?url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/power/46697|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Sieczkowski">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/25/dwayne-jones-cross-dressing-jamaican-stabbed_n_3652665.html|title=Dwayne Jones, 'Cross-Dressing' Jamaican Teen, Allegedly 'Chopped and Stabbed' to Death by Mob|newspaper=[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]|author=Sieczkowski, Cavan|accessdate=14 August 2013| date=25 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114211847/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/25/dwayne-jones-cross-dressing-jamaican-stabbed_n_3652665.html|archivedate=14 January 2016}}</ref> J-FLAG's director Dane Lewis later commented that despite an increase in homophobic violence, Jamaican society was becoming more tolerant toward LGBT people; he attributed this to the actions of individuals like Jones, who have helped improve the public visibility of LGBT people in Jamaican society.<ref name="Roberts">{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/08/12/murdered-jamaican-trans-teenager-dwayne-jones-suffered-bullying-from-father-and-at-school/|title=Murdered Jamaican trans teenager Dwayne Jones suffered bullying from father and at school|publisher=PinkNews|author=Roberts, Scott|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=12 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705225641/http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/08/12/murdered-jamaican-trans-teenager-dwayne-jones-suffered-bullying-from-father-and-at-school/|archivedate=5 July 2015}}</ref> Another LGBT rights organisation, [[Quality of Citizenship Jamaica]], issued a press release calling for the government and churches to engage with LGBT organisations to establish common ground which could be undergirded by the principle of "true respect for all," found in the nation's [[Jamaica, Land We Love|National Anthem]].<ref name="QCJ">{{cite news|url=http://qcjm.org/press-release-murder-of-17yr-old-irwin-st-james/|title=Press Release – Murder of 17yr old, Irwin St. James|publisher=Quality of Citizenship Jamaica|accessdate=15 October 2013| date=23 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705225243/http://qcjm.org/press-release-murder-of-17yr-old-irwin-st-james/|archivedate=5 July 2015}}</ref> Human rights organisation [[Jamaicans for Justice]] called on Prime Minister [[Portia Simpson-Miller]] and religious leaders to condemn the murder, also commenting on what they saw as a lack of media coverage and public outrage about the incident, adding that "we must ask ourselves what this says about us as a people."<ref name="Martinez"/>
===Internationally=== {{Quote box|width=25em|align=right|quote="The story of Dwayne Jones lies at one extreme end of a continuum of violence experienced by Jamaicans who identify as lesbian, gay, transgender, or bisexual. Nevertheless, the circumstances of [Jones'] murder provide a snapshot of the current situation facing many LGBT people in Jamaica: a high risk of violence, vulnerability heightened by poverty and family rejection, and mixed responses from both the authorities and the public."|source=— Human Rights Watch, 2014<ref name="HRWReport">{{cite web|title=Not Safe at Home: Violence and Discrimination against LGBT People in Jamaica|website=Human Rights Watch|date=21 October 2014|url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2014/10/21/not-safe-home/violence-and-discrimination-against-lgbt-people-jamaica|accessdate=19 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105041530/https://www.hrw.org/report/2014/10/21/not-safe-home/violence-and-discrimination-against-lgbt-people-jamaica|archivedate=5 January 2016}}</ref>}}
News of Jones' murder attracted international media attention, resulting in condemnation of the killing by human rights groups.<ref name="JamaicaObserver"/> Graeme Reid, the LGBT Rights Program director at Human Rights Watch in New York, issued a statement that the Jamaican government should send an "unequivocal message" that there would be "zero tolerance" of anti-LGBT violence.<ref name="IBTimes"/><ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23544130|title=Call for probe into death of Jamaica 'cross-dresser'|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=14 August 2013|date=2 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101013331/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23544130|archivedate=1 November 2013}}</ref> Reid noted that Jamaica's Prime Minister had vowed to decriminalise same-sex sexual activity in her [[Jamaican general election, 2011|2011 election campaign]] but had yet to implement that promise. He encouraged the Jamaican authorities to take action to investigate Jones' murder and to promote respect for the country's LGBT citizens.<ref name="IBTimes"/>
In a February 2014 briefing, the U.S. [[Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|Acting Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor]], [[Uzra Zeya]], cited Jones' case as well as the torture and murder of Cameroonian HIV/AIDS activist [[Eric Ohena Lembembe]] as examples of the "troubling acts of violence" against LGBT individuals that had happened across the globe in the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|author=Zeya, Uzra|title=Briefing on the Country Reports on Human Rights|date=27 February 2014|website=United States Department of State|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/rm/2014/222659.htm|accessdate=19 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113022755/http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/rm/2014/222659.htm|archivedate=13 January 2016}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, a black LGBT organisation, the [[Out and Proud Diamond Group]] (OPDG), in association with the [[Peter Tatchell|Peter Tatchell Foundation]], organised a protest outside Jamaica's London embassy on 28 August.<ref name="PinkNewsVigil">{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/08/22/london-vigil-for-murdered-jamaican-trans-teenager/|title=London vigil for murdered Jamaican trans teenager|author=Roberts, Scott|publisher=PinkNews|accessdate=23 August 2013|date=22 August 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnvcKlju?url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/08/22/london-vigil-for-murdered-jamaican-trans-teenager/|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Gleaner28">{{cite news|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/latest/article.php?id=47563|title=British Gay Rights Group Protests Dwayne Jones' Killing|author=Johnson, Jovan|newspaper=The Gleaner|accessdate=11 October 2013|date=28 August 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZnwM25eR?url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/power/47563|archivedate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Talking to press, the OPDG's Marvin Kibuuka condemned Jones' murder and called for supporters to actively oppose the persecution of LGBT people in both Jamaica and elsewhere.<ref name="PinkNewsVigil"/> Peter Tatchell later asserted that the lack of action by Simpson-Miller and the police was tantamount to colluding with those guilty of an anti-LGBT hate crime.<ref name="PinkNewsArson"/>
In her introduction to an academic study of "queerness and children's literature", Laura Robinson, an Associate Professor of English at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]], cited Jones' murder alongside the 2013 [[Russian LGBT propaganda law]] as an example in which youth issues intersected with LGBT issues. She added that Jones was a "child who did not end up having what [[Judith Butler]] calls a 'livable life'."<ref>{{cite journal|author=Robinson, Laura|title=Queerness and Children's Literature: Embracing the Negative|journal=Bookbird: A Journal of International Children's Literature|volume=52|number=1|date=January 2014|pages=v–vi|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/bookbird/v052/52.1.robinson01.html|doi=10.1353/bkb.2014.0034}}</ref>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7IgRDhESyc4 GLBTQ Report on Jones, including footage of his dancing] *[http://www.dwayneshouse.info/ Official website of the Dwayne's House charity]

{{Other people||Nazir Ahmed (disambiguation){{!}}Nazir Ahmed}} {{Use Pakistani English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Nazir Ahmed | caption =Nazir Ahmed on third right. | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1898|05|01}} | birth_place=[[Lahore]], [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab]], [[British Raj|British India]]
(now in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1973|09|30|1898|05|01}} | death_place=[[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]] | residence = | nationality=[[Pakistani people|Pakistani]] | field = [[Experimental Physics]] |influences = [[Ernest Rutherford]]{{cn|date=May 2018}} |doctoral_advisor = [[Ernest Rutherford]]{{cn|date=May 2018}} |academic_advisors = | work_institution = {{nowrap|[[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] ([[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]])}},
[[Technological Laboratory]], [[India]]
[[Federal Bureau of Statistics]] | alma_mater = [[Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College]], [[British India]]
[[University of Cambridge]], [[UK]] | known_for =[[Nuclear power in Pakistan|Nuclear power generation programme]] | prizes = Gold Medal From Pakistan Academy of Sciences. }} '''Nazir Ahmed''' (or '''Nazir Ahmad'''), [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (1 May 1898, [[Lahore]] – 30 September 1973, [[Karachi]]) was a [[Pakistani people|Pakistani]] [[experimental physicist]] and a [[chairman]] of the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) from 1956 to 1960.{{ cite web | url= https://www.scribd.com/doc/9124256/A-short-research-paper-on-the-development-of-Pakistans-nuclear-program | title = history of Pakistan's Nuclear Power Industry | author= Adeel Khan | publisher = [[Ryerson University]] | date=7 June 2001 | accessdate=22 October 2013 }} ==Life== Nazir Ahmed obtained his B.Sc. in [[physics]] from [[Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College]], [[Aligarh]] in 1919. {{cite journal |author=I.H. Qureshi |title=Recollection from the early days of the PAEC |url=http://www.thenucleuspak.org.pk/nucleus/pdf%20Special%20Issue%20Nucleus%2042(1-4)/Recollections%20from%20the%20early%20days%20of%20PAEC%20(ms602).pdf |format=PDF |journal=[[The Nucleus (journal)|The Nucleus]] |volume=42 |issue=1–2 |pages=7–11 |year=2005 |doi= |deadurl=yes }} He attended the [[University of Cambridge]], [[UK]], under the supervision of [[Ernest Rutherford]].{{rs|date=May 2018}} There he received his M.Sc. in 1923, and [[PhD]] in [[experimental physics]] in 1925. In 1930, Ahmed came back to [[India]], where he was appointed [[assistant director]] at the [[Technological Laboratory]], [[Central Cotton Committee of India]], and became its director after one year. In 1945, he was appointed member of the [[Indian Tariff Board]]. After the [[partition of India]], Ahmed migrated to [[Pakistan]], where he held various positions, such as joint secretary of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the [[Pakistan Development Board]]. In 1956 he became the first [[chairman]] of the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) until 1960. {{cite web |author=A. Gill |title=Pakistani Nuclear Program 1-5 |url=http://owlstree.blogspot.com/2006/06/pakistani-nuclear-program-1-5.html |publisher=Owl's Tree |year=2006 |accessdate=2009-03-15 }} Ahmed was involved in efforts to build a [[heavy water|heavy water plant]] at [[Multan]], but the Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation turned down his request.{{cite web|author= |title=Pakistan: Nuclear Chronology (1953-1970): March 1958 |url=http://www.nti.org/e_research/profiles/pakistan/nuclear/5593.html |publisher=[[Nuclear Threat Initiative]] |year=2005 |accessdate=2009-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008030226/http://www.nti.org/e_research/profiles/Pakistan/Nuclear/5593.html |archivedate=8 October 2008 }} In 1960, he was transferred to [[Ministry of Science and Technology]] under the administration of [[President]] [[Ayub Khan (Field Marshal)|Ayub Khan]]. == Fellowships == * An elected member of Pakistan Academy of Sciences, 1953-1970.http://www.paspk.org/fellow10.htm {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420002525/http://www.paspk.org/fellow10.htm |date=20 April 2009 }} ==Award named after Nazir Ahmad== *Dr. Nazir Ahmad Award, Pakistan Academy of Sciences. == Research papers == *Tubewell Theory and Practice, printed in [[Pakistan Academy of Sciences]] in 1979. * Survey of Fuels & Electric Power Resources in Pakistan. Nazir Ahmad (1972). == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmed, Nazir}} [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:Pakistani physicists]] [[Category:Pakistani scientists]] [[Category:Pakistani scholars]] [[Category:Alumni of the Victoria University of Manchester]] [[Category:Aligarh Muslim University alumni|Nazir, Ahmed]] [[Category:Science and technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:Fellows of Pakistan Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:1973 deaths]] [[Category:Chairpersons of the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]]
